articles.headline: U.S. Vies With Allies and Industry to Tighten China Tech Controls
articles.snippet: The Biden administration must navigate the interests of U.S. companies and allied governments as it tries to close off China’s access to advanced chips
articles.abstract: The Biden administration must navigate the interests of U.S. companies and allied governments as it tries to close off China’s access to advanced chips
articles.lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is fighting to overcome opposition from allied nations and the tech industry as it prepares to expand restrictions aimed at slowing China’s ability to make the most advanced semiconductors, which could be used to bolster Beijing’s military capacity.

articles.headline: How Economic Grievances Were Exploited in Britain’s Violent Unrest
articles.snippet: Nationalist hatred has been linked to forces like stagnant wages and declining services, even though research shows immigration helps many economies.
articles.abstract: Nationalist hatred has been linked to forces like stagnant wages and declining services, even though research shows immigration helps many economies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like many cities around Britain shaken by anti-immigrant riots over the past week, Hartlepool, a seaside town on the northeast coast, has partly recovered from the devastating waves of industrial decline that began washing over the country in the 1980s.

articles.headline: How the Olympics Warp Time
articles.snippet: Doesn’t it seem like the Paris Games have gone by fast? Imagine having your success or failure defined by thousandths of a second.
articles.abstract: Doesn’t it seem like the Paris Games have gone by fast? Imagine having your success or failure defined by thousandths of a second.
articles.lead_paragraph: Let’s say you learned to tell time on a simple, round analog clock, with 12 big numbers and two hands. The Olympic Games present a mind-bending puzzle: What if, between each of those big numbers, there were scores of smaller numbers? And what if, between the smaller numbers, there were hundreds more numbers?

articles.headline: Your Online Lender May Not Be a Bank. Here’s How to Keep Your Money Safe.
articles.snippet: The collapse of a little-known intermediary named Synapse Financial Technologies has put a spotlight on the risk that customers face when using popular banking start-ups.
articles.abstract: The collapse of a little-known intermediary named Synapse Financial Technologies has put a spotlight on the risk that customers face when using popular banking start-ups.
articles.lead_paragraph: If it looks like a bank, advertises like a bank and accepts money like a bank — it still might not be a bank.

articles.headline: How to Avoid Online Scams and What to Do if You Become a Victim
articles.snippet: Here are tips on how to dodge some of the most devastating schemes and what to do if you or someone you care about becomes ensnared.
articles.abstract: Here are tips on how to dodge some of the most devastating schemes and what to do if you or someone you care about becomes ensnared.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cybercrime is on the rise, but even the best antivirus software can’t thwart scammers who target the human psyche.

articles.headline: Harris Leads Trump in Three Key States, Times/Siena Polls Find
articles.snippet: New surveys of Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania taken this week offer the latest indication of a dramatic reversal in standing for the Democratic Party since President Biden abandoned his re-election bid.
articles.abstract: New surveys of Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania taken this week offer the latest indication of a dramatic reversal in standing for the Democratic Party since President Biden abandoned his re-election bid.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris leads former President Donald J. Trump in three crucial battleground states, according to new surveys by The New York Times and Siena College, the latest indication of a dramatic reversal in standing for Democrats after President Biden’s departure from the presidential race remade it.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer and Ruth Igielnik

articles.headline: Inside the Worst Three Weeks of Donald Trump’s 2024 Campaign
articles.snippet: People around the former and would-be president see a candidate knocked off his bearings, disoriented by his new contest with Kamala Harris and unsure of how to take her on.
articles.abstract: People around the former and would-be president see a candidate knocked off his bearings, disoriented by his new contest with Kamala Harris and unsure of how to take her on.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Aug. 2 dinner at the Bridgehampton, N.Y., home of Howard Lutnick, the Cantor Fitzgerald chief executive, was a high-powered affair. Among the roughly 130 people who dined under an air-conditioned tent were some of Donald Trump’s wealthiest supporters, including the billionaire hedge-fund financier Bill Ackman, who sat next to the former president, and Omeed Malik, the president of another fund, 1789 Capital.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan

articles.headline: When Olympic Sponsors Go Rogue
articles.snippet: LVMH and Samsung intruded on previously sacrosanct spaces at the Paris Games, angering fellow sponsors and raising concerns about a repeat at the closing ceremony.
articles.abstract: LVMH and Samsung intruded on previously sacrosanct spaces at the Paris Games, angering fellow sponsors and raising concerns about a repeat at the closing ceremony.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the French luxury goods conglomerate LVMH agreed to pay about $175 million to underwrite the organizing committee for the Paris Olympics, the company, owned by France’s richest person, Bernard Arnault, asked for more than any previous sponsor had ever done. Organizers of the Games, desperate for that cash, appeared to have said yes at every turn.

articles.headline: The Olympics’ Toughest Act: Balancing Sports and Politics
articles.snippet: The Olympics have long been a stage for political expression, for athletes who take the opportunity. Some do, while others choose to focus strictly on their sport.
articles.abstract: The Olympics have long been a stage for political expression, for athletes who take the opportunity. Some do, while others choose to focus strictly on their sport.
articles.lead_paragraph: The athletes had lost. Their time in Paris was over. And they were, in this moment of defeat by a team from a political rival, not even allowed the comfort of their homeland’s name and flag.
articles.byline: By Hannah Beech and Valerie Hopkins

articles.headline: Walz in the National Guard: A Steady Rise Ending With a Hard Decision
articles.snippet: In a military career that spanned three decades, Tim Walz achieved one of the highest enlisted ranks in the Army. Some peers took issue with the timing of his retirement.
articles.abstract: In a military career that spanned three decades, Tim Walz achieved one of the highest enlisted ranks in the Army. Some peers took issue with the timing of his retirement.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the 1980s, the U.S. military was in the middle of a transformation. The Vietnam War was over, and a force once staffed with drafted troops who had fought and died in the jungles of Southeast Asia was transitioning to ranks filled solely with volunteers.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, John Ismay and Kate Selig

articles.headline: Israel Criticized After Strike Kills Scores in Gaza
articles.snippet: Israeli officials defended the attack on a former school compound, saying Hamas was using it as a base for military operations in Gaza City.
articles.abstract: Israeli officials defended the attack on a former school compound, saying Hamas was using it as a base for military operations in Gaza City.
articles.lead_paragraph: An Israeli airstrike early Saturday hit a school compound in northern Gaza where displaced Palestinians were sheltering, killing dozens of people, according to Gazan officials.
articles.byline: By Raja Abdulrahim, Victoria Kim and Aaron Boxerman

articles.headline: Why Schools Are Racing to Ban Student Phones
articles.snippet: As the new school year starts, a wave of new laws that aim to curb distracted learning is taking effect in Indiana, Louisiana and other states.
articles.abstract: As the new school year starts, a wave of new laws that aim to curb distracted learning is taking effect in Indiana, Louisiana and other states.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cellphones have become a school scourge. More than 70 percent of high school teachers say student phone distraction is a “major problem,” according to a survey this year by Pew Research.

articles.headline: Atop ABC, a Personal Connection to Kamala Harris
articles.snippet: The candidate is a longtime friend of Dana Walden, a senior Disney executive whose portfolio includes ABC News, the host of the next debate. ABC says she does not weigh in on editorial decisions.
articles.abstract: The candidate is a longtime friend of Dana Walden, a senior Disney executive whose portfolio includes ABC News, the host of the next debate. ABC says she does not weigh in on editorial decisions.
articles.lead_paragraph: On paper, the potential for a conflict of interest seems obvious: ABC News, the host of next month’s high-stakes presidential debate, falls under the purview of a top corporate executive at Disney who happens to be longtime friends with the Democratic nominee.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Black Men Rally for Kamala Harris, and Confront an Elephant in the Room
articles.snippet: “I’m standing behind a Black woman to be president of the United States, and it doesn’t make me any less of a Black man,” said the Illinois attorney general. “I’m asking all of you all to do the same.”
articles.abstract: “I’m standing behind a Black woman to be president of the United States, and it doesn’t make me any less of a Black man,” said the Illinois attorney general. “I’m asking all of you all to do the same.”
articles.lead_paragraph: A day after Vice President Kamala Harris announced that she intended to seek the Democratic presidential nomination, more than 40,000 Black men from across the country convened on a virtual fund-raising call to discuss what the moment required of them.
articles.byline: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Erica L. Green

articles.headline: Tim Walz’s Long Relationship With China Defies Easy Stereotypes
articles.snippet: Mr. Walz, the Democrats’ vice-presidential nominee, taught in China and has visited the country around 30 times. But he has also been critical of the Chinese government’s human rights record.
articles.abstract: Mr. Walz, the Democrats’ vice-presidential nominee, taught in China and has visited the country around 30 times. But he has also been critical of the Chinese government’s human rights record.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1989, Tim Walz faced a difficult choice.
articles.byline: By Amy Qin and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Jordan Chiles Lost a Bronze Medal Because an Appeal Was Four Seconds Late
articles.snippet: An inquiry by Chiles’s coach led judges to adjust her score and give her a medal. A court ruled the inquiry came too late. Now, the I.O.C. wants her bronze back.
articles.abstract: An inquiry by Chiles’s coach led judges to adjust her score and give her a medal. A court ruled the inquiry came too late. Now, the I.O.C. wants her bronze back.
articles.lead_paragraph: After learning that she might lose the bronze medal she won in the floor exercise at the Paris Olympics — the only individual medal she won at these Summer Games — the American gymnast Jordan Chiles took to social media on Saturday and posted four broken heart emojis on a black background.

articles.headline: Spain Is Thirsty. Here’s How It Gets Water.
articles.snippet: To supply water for a number of needs, from tourism to agriculture, the country and other dry nations are increasingly relying on desalination plants that convert seawater into fresh water.
articles.abstract: To supply water for a number of needs, from tourism to agriculture, the country and other dry nations are increasingly relying on desalination plants that convert seawater into fresh water.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a fiery hot day in late June, tourists filled the cafes and hotel rooms along Spain’s Mediterranean coast, including in Torrevieja, a small city of tightly stacked apartment blocks running along a curved beach.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed and Rachel Chaundler

articles.headline: How Los Angeles Aims to Make a Profit on the 2028 Olympics
articles.snippet: The Summer Games will be the third for Los Angeles as host, but it will be a challenge to repeat the financial success of 1984.
articles.abstract: The Summer Games will be the third for Los Angeles as host, but it will be a challenge to repeat the financial success of 1984.
articles.lead_paragraph: What Paris Olympics? Los Angeles is already looking ahead.

articles.headline: The Filipinos Living in the Shadow of China’s Military Might
articles.snippet: More than 200 civilian settlers on a contested island in the South China Sea find themselves on the frontier of a possible conflict with China.
articles.abstract: More than 200 civilian settlers on a contested island in the South China Sea find themselves on the frontier of a possible conflict with China.
articles.lead_paragraph: For travelers flying into the tiny island of Thitu, the reality of China’s territorial ambition becomes instantly clear. There they are: dozens of Chinese ships surrounding a speck of land that a few hundred Filipinos call home.
articles.byline: By Camille Elemia and Jes Aznar

articles.headline: Uber, Facing Sexual-Assault Litigation, Pushes Plan That May Curb Suits
articles.snippet: Uber has spent millions trying to get a proposal on the Nevada ballot that would restrict the legal fees that bankroll many lawsuits against companies.
articles.abstract: Uber has spent millions trying to get a proposal on the Nevada ballot that would restrict the legal fees that bankroll many lawsuits against companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been a decades-long dream of corporate America: making it harder for aggrieved customers, workers and others to file lawsuits against companies seeking compensation for alleged injuries, mistreatment and other harms.

articles.headline: Brands Love Influencers (Until Politics Get Involved)
articles.snippet: Marketing firms are using artificial intelligence to help analyze influencers and predict whether they will opine about the election.
articles.abstract: Marketing firms are using artificial intelligence to help analyze influencers and predict whether they will opine about the election.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brands love when social media stars take to Instagram or TikTok to advertise their soap, probiotic sodas, makeup and more. But many of those same brands are eager to avoid influencers who discuss politics.

articles.headline: Elections Officials Battle a Deluge of Disinformation
articles.snippet: County clerks and secretaries of state are overwhelmed this year, as they stare down a “perpetual moving target” of new conspiracy theories, political pressure and threats.
articles.abstract: County clerks and secretaries of state are overwhelmed this year, as they stare down a “perpetual moving target” of new conspiracy theories, political pressure and threats.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tate Fall is overwhelmed.
